source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_035_chunk1
evidence_span: The mechanical properties of the final tubes depend on the final heat treatment and slightly on the first steps of the fabrication sequence, leading to small differences in the grain size.
process_step: final heat treatment, first fabrication steps

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_035_chunk1
evidence_span: The nodular corrosion sensitivity of the recrystallized cladding tubes points out the influence of the early fabrication steps: The increase of the alpha annealing temperature in any fabrication step is detrimental.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_035_chunk1
evidence_span: Among the tubes tested in this program those with the best nodular corrosion resistance in the high-pressure steam test had the worst behavior using ASTM Practice for Aqueous Corrosion Testing of Samples of Zirconium and Zirconium Alloys (G 2).

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_035_chunk1
evidence_span: During the ASTM G 2 test the weight gain of the external surface of the tubes was higher than the weight gain of the internal surface.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_035_chunk1
evidence_span: The mechanical properties and the ductility of tubes are influenced by structure, texture, and composition [1,2]

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_035_chunk1
evidence_span: It was found that a high cooling rate from the beta or alpha-plus-beta range is the best way to achieve products with good nodular corrosion resistance in a high-pressure steam test [3]

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_035_chunk1
evidence_span: subsequent hot working, and alpha annealing after cold rolling, led to a decrease in the nodular corrosion resistance [4]
process_step: hot working, alpha annealing, cold rolling

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_035_chunk1
evidence_span: A 6-ton ingot of Zircaloy-4 produced from multiple vacuum-arc melts was broken down in the beta range into bars of $1 8 0 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ diameter
